Award.AwardTitle: A Computational Survey of Excitable Competence Circuits in Bacillus subtilis

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is a theoretical investigation focused on the phenomenon of competence in Bacillus subtilis. Competence is the state during which this bacterium can accept and incorporate, into its own genome, DNA from the environment. The competent state is adopted at random times and for random durations and is thought to be an evolutionary strategy to facilitate adaptation to changing environmental stress. In this project computational and simulation approaches will be used 1) to develop hypotheses for plausible theoretical gene regulation topologies that underlie competence, and 2) to compute, numerically, their observable phenotypes. The approach consists of systematically simulating the stochastic behavior of the hypothetical gene regulatory circuit topologies. The work includes deriving, analytically, the continuous limit of each model; it involves connecting the discrete and continuous models, and performing phase plane analyses. Parameter continuation will be used to map the dynamical regimes of these systems. Comparisons with the stochastic behavior will be made and differences leading to potentially interesting biological phenotypes will be identified. The project is expected to suggest new gene regulation circuits to "reengineer" in the bacterium and test in the laboratory. Key issues that are addressed in this project concern the redistribution of noise in gene regulatory networks as a function of circuit topology; whether general principles of noise conservation (or trade off) exist; and the extent to which such principles might inform our understanding of evolutionary processes.

Broader Impacts: This project will provide training at the interface of mathematics, computer simulation and biology for undergraduate and graduate students, and for a postdoctoral fellow who is interested in using mathematics and computational simulations in the study of biology. The STARS program (Science Teacher Access to Resources at Southwestern) will provide opportunities for high-school teachers and their students to become engaged in this project. New educational programs at the interface of mathematics and biology will be developed, together with new portable simulation-oriented teaching material for direct use in the classroom. STARS will facilitate interactions with the Dallas Independent School District (DISD) schools and provide access to this project for traditionally underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Despite their puzzling complexity, living systems are governed by the same physical laws that organize and maintain everything in the world around us. Those laws are nothing but the laws of physics and, ultimately, mathematics. So it is not surprising that mathematics has so much to do with not only the "how" living systems work, but most importantly the "why" they work the way they do. Hence, mathematics has to do with why Evolution has made, and continues to make the choices it makes. That Evolution proceeds randomly to optimize phenotype for function is true, but it can only pick from what makes mathematical sense. This is where the power of mathematical analysis comes in: as a way to recapitulate evolutionary choices.


It is impossible to recapitulate all of Evolution. But fortunately this is not necessary, we can use theory instead. From the underlying mathematics, one can formulate educated hypotheses about what could have been tried by Evolution and then use computational analysis to deduce the consequences for a living organism under the control of altered genetic regulation. This is exactly what my project was about, in a nutshell: to investigate the “why” rather than the “how”. I used nonlinear dynamics, a branch of applied mathematics, and stochastic simulations, common to many fields such as engineering and even finance, to simulate and understand the behavior of slightly modified gene regulation circuits of a common bacterium, and for a set of progressively more complex core regulatory commitment circuits found in the field of development.
In the first part of the project, I installed an additional auto-regulation loop to the core genetic circuit that controls the phenotype of competence in a common bacterium called Bacillus subtilis. In the first instance, I modified the circuit found in the normal bacterium. In the second instance, I modified the circuit found in an artificial mutant of this circuit, a mutant already known to break the phenotype of competence, but in very subtle way: rendering it more regular than random, more clock-like than stochastic. The modifications I made were all in the mathematical models describing the behavior of the gene regulatory circuits.  I then proceeded to run massive simulations using weeks, sometimes even several months of integrated computing time to generate data from which the behavior of the hypothetical, yet evolutionary plausible, regulatory circuits, could be extracted.  In two prototype circuits, using simulations, this research discovered multiple reasons why the circuits would lead to behavior breaking the phenotype of bacterial competence. Thus the research explicitly showed why Evolution could not have picked these circuits.


In the second part of the project, I studied several progressively more complex core genetic differentiation (commitment) circuits. I computed their bifurcation diagrams as a function of parameter asymmetry, the difference in the back-and-forth influence of pairs of genes in the systems. Parameter asymmetry is expected in living systems but in fact, the mathematics predicts that it breaks the commitment phenotype in simple positively auto-regulated mutually repressive two-gene circuits. My studies confirmed this, but I also found that, in more complex circuits (three, four and five genes), asymmetry induced oscillatory regimes would also break the commitment phenotype. But most interestingly, systems with progressively more genes tend to push off the rotation to dynamical regions outside the biologically meaningful regime.  Actually, multi-gene core regulatory control circuits seem to be preferred by Evolution and my studies support this notion.
